pros: The 180DC Cambridge team introduced a very structured and well-managed programme that allowed consultants in university to work on their consulting skills and networking while developing their deliverables for each client
cons: Nothing significant to mention for the experience

review_title: Challenging and Impactful Experience at 180 Degrees Consulting
pros: Impactful projects: As a consultant at 180 Degrees Consulting, I've had the opportunity to work on projects that create a tangible impact on non-profits and social enterprises. This experience has been fulfilling and allowed me to apply my skills towards meaningful goals. Diverse clientele: The diverse range of clients I've worked with has allowed me to gain exposure to various industries and social issues. This has broadened my understanding of the challenges faced by different organizations and has helped me develop a more versatile skill set. Supportive team culture: The team at 180 Degrees is incredibly supportive and collaborative. Everyone is eager to help each other out, and there is a strong emphasis on mentorship and professional development. This creates a positive working environment where I feel comfortable asking questions and seeking guidance. Skill development: As a consultant, I've had ample opportunities to develop my problem-solving, communication, and project management skills. These skills have not only been valuable in my role but also have prepared me for future career opportunities.
cons: Workload: At times, the workload can be quite demanding as a student, especially when balancing multiple projects or when working on a project with a tight deadline. This can lead to some long hours and occasional stress. Limited resources: As a non-profit consulting firm, 180 Degrees sometimes lacks the resources and access to cutting-edge tools that larger, for-profit consulting firms may have. However, this also fosters creativity in problem-solving and encourages the development of innovative solutions.

job_title: BSc Economics With German Student in Birmingham, England
pros: Good opportunity to make a difference. Also helped me improve my German as an Erasmus student, plus the clients were very nice.
cons: Lack of support offered to my consulting group throughout the process from 180DC. There was a definite misunderstanding between us and the autism charity we were helping - I think they thought that they would be getting a high-quality professional service. We were professional but only students who had just started out, so there was unfortunately a real limit to what we could do. I hated the feeling of letting the autism charity down but I do think they were led to expect a professional experienced level of service, which we as rookie students just couldn't provide. All of my group quit after just the 1 semester doing it.

pros: I was for one semester a student consultant at 180 Degrees Consulting. I really enjoyed the cases and the whole atmosphere. I met many like-minded internationals. The whole team spirit and atmosphere made it to a great experience. I also learned a lot in how to approach companies, how to make use of different kind of analysis. Also loved our weekly brainstorming meetings. I can highly recommend being a student consultant even though it means working on a pro-bono basis. The people, the culture and the experience is it worth.
cons: I think they changed the application procedure into an AC (at least in Vienna) I think thats a bit tough for a pro bono job.

pros: Great org with great people and great vision. The goal is probably one of the best things in the world; they truly prioritze helping and making a difference instead of just making money

Rigid structure in terms of communications. Consulting recommendations were not data driven or research backed, and were very much based on guesswork.
